The CAB structure has, however, been criticized for many reasons. One is that of inadequate attention to the research literacy needs of the community and lack of legitimacy given to research, regardless of whether the recommendations of the CAB are reflected in the research design and conduct.

Folayan, M.O., Haire, B., Peterson, K., et al. (2015). Stakeholder engagement with Ebola therapy research in resource limited setting. BMC Infect Dis. 15(1), 242. The CAB may still function as a bridge between the community and the research if its members are designated by the community, not picked by the research team, who often have no allegiance to a community.

Folayan, M.O., Durueke, F., Wikka, G., et al. (2019). Community engagement during a vaccine demonstration project in Nigeria: challenges and successes with implementation of the good participatory practice guidelines. Pan African Medical Journal. 34, 179. Also, community education about COVID‐19 and the trial should be conducted through channels accessible by the community members and not only by community advisory board members.
